trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager support for Traffic Manager Preview | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager support for Traffic Manager Preview | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Using powershell for Traffic Manager with Azure Resource Manager (ARM) in preview
trans-unit.target: Using powershell for Traffic Manager with Azure Resource Manager (ARM) in preview

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager support for Azure Traffic Manager Preview
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager support for Azure Traffic Manager Preview

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) is the new management framework for services in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager (ARM) is the new management framework for services in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Azure Traffic Manager profiles can now be managed using Azure Resource Manager-based APIs and tools.
trans-unit.target: Azure Traffic Manager profiles can now be managed using Azure Resource Manager-based APIs and tools.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Azure Resource Manager, see [Using Resource groups to manage your Azure resources](../azure-preview-portal-using-resource-groups.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Azure Resource Manager, see [Using Resource groups to manage your Azure resources](../azure-preview-portal-using-resource-groups.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] ARM support for Traffic Manager is currently in Preview, including REST API, Azure PowerShell, Azure CLI and .NET SDK.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] ARM support for Traffic Manager is currently in Preview, including REST API, Azure PowerShell, Azure CLI and .NET SDK.

trans-unit.source: Resource model
trans-unit.target: Resource model

trans-unit.source: Azure Traffic Manager is configured using a collection of settings called a Traffic Manager profile.
trans-unit.target: Azure Traffic Manager is configured using a collection of settings called a Traffic Manager profile.

trans-unit.source: This contains DNS settings, traffic routing settings, endpoint monitoring settings and the list of service endpoints to which traffic will be routed.
trans-unit.target: This contains DNS settings, traffic routing settings, endpoint monitoring settings and the list of service endpoints to which traffic will be routed.

trans-unit.source: In ARM, each Traffic Manager profile is represented by an ARM resource, of type ‘TrafficManagerProfiles’, managed by the ‘Microsoft.Network’ resource provider.
trans-unit.target: In ARM, each Traffic Manager profile is represented by an ARM resource, of type ‘TrafficManagerProfiles’, managed by the ‘Microsoft.Network’ resource provider.

trans-unit.source: At the REST API level, the URI for each profile is as follows:
trans-unit.target: At the REST API level, the URI for each profile is as follows:

trans-unit.source: Comparison with the Azure Traffic Manager Service Management API
trans-unit.target: Comparison with the Azure Traffic Manager Service Management API

trans-unit.source: Using ARM to configure Traffic Manager profiles provides access to the same set of Traffic Manager features as the (non-ARM) service management API, with the exception of the Preview Limitations listed below.
trans-unit.target: Using ARM to configure Traffic Manager profiles provides access to the same set of Traffic Manager features as the (non-ARM) service management API, with the exception of the Preview Limitations listed below.

trans-unit.source: However, whilst the features remain the same, some terminology has changed:
trans-unit.target: However, whilst the features remain the same, some terminology has changed:

trans-unit.source: The ‘load-balancing method’, which determines how Traffic Manager choose which endpoint to route traffic to when responding to a particular DNS request, has been renamed ‘traffic routing method’.
trans-unit.target: The ‘load-balancing method’, which determines how Traffic Manager choose which endpoint to route traffic to when responding to a particular DNS request, has been renamed ‘traffic routing method’.

trans-unit.source: The ‘round robin’ traffic routing method has been renamed ‘weighted’.
trans-unit.target: The ‘round robin’ traffic routing method has been renamed ‘weighted’.

trans-unit.source: The ‘failover’ traffic routing method has been renamed ‘priority’.
trans-unit.target: The ‘failover’ traffic routing method has been renamed ‘priority’.

trans-unit.source: Preview limitations
trans-unit.target: Preview limitations

trans-unit.source: As the Azure Resource Manager support for Traffic Manager is a Preview service, there are currently a small number of limitations:
trans-unit.target: As the Azure Resource Manager support for Traffic Manager is a Preview service, there are currently a small number of limitations:

trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager profiles created using the existing (non-ARM) service management API, tools and Portal are not available via ARM, and vice versa.
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager profiles created using the existing (non-ARM) service management API, tools and Portal are not available via ARM, and vice versa.

trans-unit.source: Migration of profiles from non-ARM to ARM APIs is not currently supported.
trans-unit.target: Migration of profiles from non-ARM to ARM APIs is not currently supported.

trans-unit.source: The REST API does not support PATCHing of Traffic Manager profiles.
trans-unit.target: The REST API does not support PATCHing of Traffic Manager profiles.

trans-unit.source: To update a profile property, you must GET the profile, and PUT the modified profile.
trans-unit.target: To update a profile property, you must GET the profile, and PUT the modified profile.

trans-unit.source: Only ‘external’ endpoints are supported.
trans-unit.target: Only ‘external’ endpoints are supported.

trans-unit.source: These can still be used to use Traffic Manager with Azure-based services, and when doing so those endpoints will be billed at the internal endpoint rate.
trans-unit.target: These can still be used to use Traffic Manager with Azure-based services, and when doing so those endpoints will be billed at the internal endpoint rate.

trans-unit.source: (The only impact of using external endpoints is that they will not be disabled or deleted automatically if the underlying Azure service is disabled or deleted, instead you will have to disable or delete the endpoint manually).
trans-unit.target: (The only impact of using external endpoints is that they will not be disabled or deleted automatically if the underlying Azure service is disabled or deleted, instead you will have to disable or delete the endpoint manually).

trans-unit.source: Azure Traffic Manager is not yet available in the Azure portal, only on the classic portal.
trans-unit.target: Azure Traffic Manager is not yet available in the Azure portal, only on the classic portal.

trans-unit.source: Setting up Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Setting up Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: These instructions use Microsoft Azure PowerShell, which needs to be configured using the steps below.
trans-unit.target: These instructions use Microsoft Azure PowerShell, which needs to be configured using the steps below.

trans-unit.source: For non-PowerShell users, the same operations can also be executed via the other interfaces.
trans-unit.target: For non-PowerShell users, the same operations can also be executed via the other interfaces.

trans-unit.source: Step 1
trans-unit.target: Step 1

trans-unit.source: Install the latest Azure PowerShell, available from the Azure downloads page.
trans-unit.target: Install the latest Azure PowerShell, available from the Azure downloads page.

trans-unit.source: Step 2
trans-unit.target: Step 2

trans-unit.source: Switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Switch PowerShell mode to use the ARM cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: More info is available at Using Windows Powershell with Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: More info is available at Using Windows Powershell with Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Step 3
trans-unit.target: Step 3

trans-unit.source: Log in to your Azure account.
trans-unit.target: Log in to your Azure account.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to Authenticate with your credentials.

trans-unit.source: Step 4
trans-unit.target: Step 4

trans-unit.source: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.
trans-unit.target: Choose which of your Azure subscriptions to use.

trans-unit.source: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To see a list of available subscriptions, use the ‘Get-AzureSubscription’ cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Step 5
trans-unit.target: Step 5

trans-unit.source: The Traffic Manager service is managed by the Microsoft.Network resource provider.
trans-unit.target: The Traffic Manager service is managed by the Microsoft.Network resource provider.

trans-unit.source: Your Azure subscription needs to be registered to use this resource provider before you can use Traffic Manager via ARM.
trans-unit.target: Your Azure subscription needs to be registered to use this resource provider before you can use Traffic Manager via ARM.

trans-unit.source: This is a one-time operation for each subscription.
trans-unit.target: This is a one-time operation for each subscription.

trans-unit.source: Step 6
trans-unit.target: Step 6

trans-unit.source: Create a resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)
trans-unit.target: Create a resource group (skip this step if using an existing resource group)

trans-unit.source: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.
trans-unit.target: Azure Resource Manager requires that all resource groups specify a location.

trans-unit.source: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.
trans-unit.target: This is used as the default location for resources in that resource group.

trans-unit.source: However, since all Traffic Manager profile resources are global, not regional, the choice of resource group location has no impact on Azure Traffic Manager.
trans-unit.target: However, since all Traffic Manager profile resources are global, not regional, the choice of resource group location has no impact on Azure Traffic Manager.

trans-unit.source: Create a Traffic Manager Profile
trans-unit.target: Create a Traffic Manager Profile

trans-unit.source: To create a Traffic Manager profile, use the New-AzureTrafficManagerProfile cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To create a Traffic Manager profile, use the New-AzureTrafficManagerProfile cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: The parameters are as follows:
trans-unit.target: The parameters are as follows:

trans-unit.source: Name: The ARM resource name for the Traffic Manager profile resource.
trans-unit.target: Name: The ARM resource name for the Traffic Manager profile resource.

trans-unit.source: Profiles in the same resource group must have unique names.
trans-unit.target: Profiles in the same resource group must have unique names.

trans-unit.source: This name is separate from the DNS name used for DNS queries.
trans-unit.target: This name is separate from the DNS name used for DNS queries.

trans-unit.source: ResourceGroupName: The name of the ARM resource group containing the profile resource.
trans-unit.target: ResourceGroupName: The name of the ARM resource group containing the profile resource.

trans-unit.source: TrafficRoutingMethod: Specifies the traffic routing method, used to determine which endpoint is returned in response to incoming DNS queries.
trans-unit.target: TrafficRoutingMethod: Specifies the traffic routing method, used to determine which endpoint is returned in response to incoming DNS queries.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are ‘Performance’, ‘Weighted’ or ‘Priority’.
trans-unit.target: Possible values are ‘Performance’, ‘Weighted’ or ‘Priority’.

trans-unit.source: RelativeDnsName: Specifies the relative DNS name provided by this Traffic Manager profile.
trans-unit.target: RelativeDnsName: Specifies the relative DNS name provided by this Traffic Manager profile.

trans-unit.source: This value is combined with the DNS domain name used by Azure Traffic Manager to form the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the profile.
trans-unit.target: This value is combined with the DNS domain name used by Azure Traffic Manager to form the fully-qualified domain name (FQDN) of the profile.

trans-unit.source: For example, the value ‘contoso’ will give a Traffic Manager profile with the fully-qualified name ‘contoso.trafficmanager.net’.
trans-unit.target: For example, the value ‘contoso’ will give a Traffic Manager profile with the fully-qualified name ‘contoso.trafficmanager.net’.

trans-unit.source: TTL: Specifies the DNS Time-to-Live (TTL), in seconds.
trans-unit.target: TTL: Specifies the DNS Time-to-Live (TTL), in seconds.

trans-unit.source: This informs the Local DNS resolvers and DNS clients how long to cache DNS responses provided by this Traffic Manager profile.
trans-unit.target: This informs the Local DNS resolvers and DNS clients how long to cache DNS responses provided by this Traffic Manager profile.

trans-unit.source: MonitorProtocol: Specifies the protocol to use to monitor endpoint health.
trans-unit.target: MonitorProtocol: Specifies the protocol to use to monitor endpoint health.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are ‘HTTP’ and ‘HTTPS’.
trans-unit.target: Possible values are ‘HTTP’ and ‘HTTPS’.

trans-unit.source: MonitorPort: Specifies the TCP port used to monitor endpoint health.
trans-unit.target: MonitorPort: Specifies the TCP port used to monitor endpoint health.

trans-unit.source: MonitorPath: Specifies the path relative to the endpoint domain name used to probe for endpoint health.
trans-unit.target: MonitorPath: Specifies the path relative to the endpoint domain name used to probe for endpoint health.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet creates a Traffic Manager profile in Azure Traffic Manager and returns a corresponding profile object.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet creates a Traffic Manager profile in Azure Traffic Manager and returns a corresponding profile object.

trans-unit.source: At this point, the profile does not contain any endpoints—see [Update a Traffic Manager Profile](#update-a-traffic-manager-profile) for details of how to add endpoints to a Traffic Manager profile.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the profile does not contain any endpoints—see [Update a Traffic Manager Profile](#update-a-traffic-manager-profile) for details of how to add endpoints to a Traffic Manager profile.

trans-unit.source: Get a Traffic Manager Profile
trans-unit.target: Get a Traffic Manager Profile

trans-unit.source: To retrieve an existing Traffic Manager profile object, use the Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfle cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To retrieve an existing Traffic Manager profile object, use the Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfle cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet returns a Traffic Manager profile object.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet returns a Traffic Manager profile object.

trans-unit.source: Update a Traffic Manager Profile [](#update-traffic-manager-profile)
trans-unit.target: Update a Traffic Manager Profile [](#update-traffic-manager-profile)

trans-unit.source: Modifying Traffic Manager profiles, for example to add or remove endpoints or modify profile settings, follows a 3-step process:
trans-unit.target: Modifying Traffic Manager profiles, for example to add or remove endpoints or modify profile settings, follows a 3-step process:

trans-unit.source: Retrieve the profile using Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile (or use the profile returned by New-AzureTrafficManagerProfile).
trans-unit.target: Retrieve the profile using Get-AzureTrafficManagerProfile (or use the profile returned by New-AzureTrafficManagerProfile).

trans-unit.source: Modify the profile, by either adding endpoints, removing endpoints, changing the endpoint parameters or changing profile paramters.
trans-unit.target: Modify the profile, by either adding endpoints, removing endpoints, changing the endpoint parameters or changing profile paramters.

trans-unit.source: These changes are off-line—only the local object representing the profile is changed.
trans-unit.target: These changes are off-line—only the local object representing the profile is changed.

trans-unit.source: Commit your changes using the Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Commit your changes using the Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: This replaces the existing profile in Azure Traffic Manager with the profile provided.
trans-unit.target: This replaces the existing profile in Azure Traffic Manager with the profile provided.

trans-unit.source: This can be further explained using the examples below:
trans-unit.target: This can be further explained using the examples below:

trans-unit.source: Add endpoints to a Profile
trans-unit.target: Add endpoints to a Profile

trans-unit.source: Endpoints can be added to a Traffic Manager profile using the ‘Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpointConfig’ cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: Endpoints can be added to a Traffic Manager profile using the ‘Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpointConfig’ cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: The parameters to Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpointConfig are as follows:
trans-unit.target: The parameters to Add-AzureTrafficManagerEndpointConfig are as follows:

trans-unit.source: EndpointName: The name of the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: EndpointName: The name of the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Endpoints in the same profile must have distinct names.
trans-unit.target: Endpoints in the same profile must have distinct names.

trans-unit.source: This is used to reference the endpoint during service management operations, it is not the DNS name of the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: This is used to reference the endpoint during service management operations, it is not the DNS name of the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: TrafficManagerProfile: The Traffic Manager profile object to which the endpoint will be added.
trans-unit.target: TrafficManagerProfile: The Traffic Manager profile object to which the endpoint will be added.

trans-unit.source: Type: The type of the Traffic Manager endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Type: The type of the Traffic Manager endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Currently, only the ‘ExternalEndpoint’ type is supported via the ARM API (see [Preview Limitations](#preview-limitations)).
trans-unit.target: Currently, only the ‘ExternalEndpoint’ type is supported via the ARM API (see [Preview Limitations](#preview-limitations)).

trans-unit.source: Target: The fully-qualified DNS name of the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Target: The fully-qualified DNS name of the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager returns this value in DNS responses to direct traffic to this endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager returns this value in DNS responses to direct traffic to this endpoint.

trans-unit.source: EndpointStatus: Specifies the status of the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: EndpointStatus: Specifies the status of the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: If the endpoint is Enabled, it is probed for endpoint health and is included in the traffic routing method.
trans-unit.target: If the endpoint is Enabled, it is probed for endpoint health and is included in the traffic routing method.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are ‘Enabled’ or ‘Disabled’.
trans-unit.target: Possible values are ‘Enabled’ or ‘Disabled’.

trans-unit.source: Weight: Specifies the weight assigned to the endpoint.
trans-unit.target: Weight: Specifies the weight assigned to the endpoint.

trans-unit.source: This is only used if the Traffic Manager profile is configured to use the 'weighted' traffic routing method.
trans-unit.target: This is only used if the Traffic Manager profile is configured to use the 'weighted' traffic routing method.

trans-unit.source: Possible values are from 1 to 1000.
trans-unit.target: Possible values are from 1 to 1000.

trans-unit.source: Priority: Specifies the priority of this endpoint when using the ‘priority’ traffic routing method.
trans-unit.target: Priority: Specifies the priority of this endpoint when using the ‘priority’ traffic routing method.

trans-unit.source: Priority must lie in the range 1…1000.
trans-unit.target: Priority must lie in the range 1…1000.

trans-unit.source: Lower values represent higher priority.
trans-unit.target: Lower values represent higher priority.

trans-unit.source: EndpointLocation: Specifies the location of the external endpoint, for use with the ‘Performance’ traffic routing method.
trans-unit.target: EndpointLocation: Specifies the location of the external endpoint, for use with the ‘Performance’ traffic routing method.

trans-unit.source: For a list of possible locations, see Get-AzureLocation.
trans-unit.target: For a list of possible locations, see Get-AzureLocation.

trans-unit.source: Endpoint Status, Weight and Priority are optional parameters.
trans-unit.target: Endpoint Status, Weight and Priority are optional parameters.

trans-unit.source: If omitted, they are not passed by PowerShell and the server-side defaults apply.
trans-unit.target: If omitted, they are not passed by PowerShell and the server-side defaults apply.

trans-unit.source: Remove endpoints from a Profile
trans-unit.target: Remove endpoints from a Profile

trans-unit.source: To remove an endpoint from a profile, use ‘Remove-AzureTrafficmanagerEndpointConfig’, specifying the name of the endpoint to be removed:
trans-unit.target: To remove an endpoint from a profile, use ‘Remove-AzureTrafficmanagerEndpointConfig’, specifying the name of the endpoint to be removed:

trans-unit.source: The sequence of operations to add or remove endpoints can also be ‘piped’, passing the profile object via the pipe instead of as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: The sequence of operations to add or remove endpoints can also be ‘piped’, passing the profile object via the pipe instead of as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Change profile or endpoint settings
trans-unit.target: Change profile or endpoint settings

trans-unit.source: Both profile and endpoint parameters can be changed off-line, and the changes committed using Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile.
trans-unit.target: Both profile and endpoint parameters can be changed off-line, and the changes committed using Set-AzureTrafficManagerProfile.

trans-unit.source: The only exception is that the profile RelativeDnsName cannot be changed after the profile is created (to change this value, delete and re-create the profile).
trans-unit.target: The only exception is that the profile RelativeDnsName cannot be changed after the profile is created (to change this value, delete and re-create the profile).

trans-unit.source: For example, to change the profile TTL and the status of the first endpoint:
trans-unit.target: For example, to change the profile TTL and the status of the first endpoint:

trans-unit.source: Delete a Traffic Manager Profile
trans-unit.target: Delete a Traffic Manager Profile

trans-unit.source: To delete a Traffic Manager profile, use the Remove-AzureTrafficManagerProfile cmdlet, specifying the profile name and resource group name:
trans-unit.target: To delete a Traffic Manager profile, use the Remove-AzureTrafficManagerProfile cmdlet, specifying the profile name and resource group name:

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet will prompt for confirmation.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet will prompt for confirmation.

trans-unit.source: The optional ‘-Force’ switch can be used to suppress this prompt.
trans-unit.target: The optional ‘-Force’ switch can be used to suppress this prompt.

trans-unit.source: The profile to be deleted can also be specified using a profile object:
trans-unit.target: The profile to be deleted can also be specified using a profile object:

trans-unit.target: This sequence can also be piped:
